Disneyland Paris at 40: When Mickey Mouse said 'bonjour' to Paris
subhead: On December 18, 1985, the Walt Disney Company approved the construction of its first European theme park in Marne-la-Vallée, about 30 kilometers east of Paris. The prime minister secured the deal after tough negotiations between envoys from the Socialist government and an American corporation seen as the embodiment of ruthless capitalism.

title: Australian state pushes tough gun laws and implements ban on 'terror symbols' after mass shooting
Trump administration denies cover-up over redacted Epstein files
In Turkey, Renault's vast factory anchors a booming auto hub geared toward Europe
subhead: At the Bursa plant of French carmaker Renault, 5,600 employees and 800 robots churn out the brand's best-selling models. The site sits at the heart of a sprawling ecosystem of manufacturers, including Stellantis and Toyota, that feed the European Union's demand for new cars.

title: In Paris, an almost unknown chapel is drawing millions of tourists
subhead: By 2025, Notre-Dame-de-la-Médaille-Miraculeuse in Paris will have welcomed around three million visitors from across the globe. This is a record, and yet it remains almost entirely unknown to Parisians.

title: In 'Avatar: Fire and Ash,' James Cameron's Na'vi lose faith
subhead: The third installment of the saga on the planet Pandora finds its inhabitants transformed into nihilist punks, ready to collaborate with their human colonizers.

title: Syria through a photographer's lens: 'We began working on stories that Assad's regime forbade us to cover'
subhead: One year ago, a group of Syrian rebels announced they had taken Damascus, ending the rule of Bashar al-Assad. Photographer Laurence Geai has since traveled to the country three times for Le Monde. She shares her work with us.

title: Madagascar's metalheads lead charge of anger: 'It's easier to make yourself heard when you scream'
subhead: After three weeks of protest, Madagascar's Generation Z succeeded in toppling those in power on October 14. The uprising drew much of its strength from countercultural circles, chief among them the island's vibrant metal scene. Heirs to a long tradition, Madagascar's metalheads condemn poverty, inequality and the regime's incompetence.
byline: By Jean-Philippe Rémy (Antananarivo, Madagascar, special correspondent)

title: Lumpy skin disease: Farmers demand vaccines and reject culling
subhead: After vaccination zones and a protection zone were implemented in the Occitanie region of southern France, concern is now growing in the Aveyron. The department, home to 500,000 cattle, has the largest herd in the region, with half of them being the Aubrac breed.

title: Trump and the 'derangement syndrome' driving people crazy
subhead: To discredit the president's opponents, the Make America Great Again movement has coined the phrase 'Trump derangement syndrome': a supposed mental illness that explains their systematic opposition. While the psychiatric argument for this has not been proven, many Democrats attest to the anger they feel every time the president speaks.
